title: Is the PLI Scheme thatâ€™s subsidising mobile phone manufacturing a value add to the Indian economy?
selftext:
As per Raghuram Rajan, the PLI scheme is not adding value, given that the govt is funding 6% of the invoice of iPhones manufactured in India. Even if we have become a net exporter of mobile phones to the tune of $10 billion, overall, we are now a net importer to the tune of $ 20 billion if we add up the imports of components from China. So essentially, we arenâ€™t capturing a large portion of the value chain to justify the 6% subsidy, and we have become a much larger importer than before, which is poles opposite to what the PLI scheme was supposed to do. 

Here's my questionðŸ˜‰

Is every taxpaying Indian contributing a small percentage of their income/time to produce iPhones? 

Which means that when taxpayers buy iPhones, then they are cherishing the fruit of their own labour :D 

I don't know why I'm reminded of the East India Company that bought raw materials from India and sold the finished products back to us. 

I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m oversimplifying or if Iâ€™m outright wrong.
